comment_text:
I have found the perfect diet. It’s easy. And simple to live with forever. It’s called The Carbohydrate Addict’s Diet. Basically it’s eating one carbohydrate meal a day. Anything for one hour. The other meal is very low carb. Like steak and eggs. No toast and jelly. Or tofu and broccoli. Or pickles olives or cheese. Salad! No croutons and careful about the dressing. No more than four carbs. Nuts yes. That’s the idea. It works. By not releasing insulin more than once daily. Try to stick to the same meal. I’ve chosen lunch as my “ carb meal “. I’m telling you that 36 hours in and all cravings and hunger is gone. I do kinda focus pretty good on that carb meal though cuz it’s my treat. I eat pretty healthy anyway. Fruit is my dessert. But you could literally eat pizza and donuts for only that one hour a day. You lose between 1&2 pounds a week. So maybe 50+ pounds in a year. Add any healthy activity of course. But for the diet it’s unnecessary… 🤷🏼‍♀️ 
Research it. There’s a book. By the diet’s name. Blessings in all truth.

comment_text:
I really relate to this. When I was on HRT, my dose kept getting increased, but it only made me feel worse. It felt like it was fighting with my nervous system — I could feel the cortisol and adrenaline rushing, the rage, sugar cravings, the overstimulation. The answer from doctors was always “more HRT” or antidepressants.

Two weeks ago, I quit HRT, caffeine, and sugar  and  started eating foods to heal — and within 15 days my body feels so much more balanced. No more waking in the night with cortisol spikes, no more constant crashes. My mind is clearer, my energy steadier, and I finally feel like I’m resetting instead of spiralling. I've lost 18lb and 8 inch of my belly !

video_title: Hormone Expert: Control Your Hormones Control Your Belly Fat! Cortisol, oestrogen, testosterone.
comment_text: Subcutaneous fat in menopausal women functions as a natural factory for estradiol.  Don't try to significantly lose weight because you will lose the last resource to save your health in the menopause. Just a small logic lesson: When the ovaries stop functioning, estrogen production also stops, but testosterone continues to be produced in the adrenal glands. Subcutaneous fat acts as an aromatizer of testosterone to estradiol, so this is how nature has arranged for menopausal women to be protected. If you don't have subcutaneous fat as woman in menopause, you won't have estrogen and your health will start to deteriorate. An alternative is hormone therapy, but not every doctor knows how to set it up properly (especially if they don't have your hormonal profile from your youth when you still had your period). Subcutaneous fat is your friend, not the enemy!

video_title: Hormone Expert: Control Your Hormones Control Your Belly Fat! Cortisol, oestrogen, testosterone.
comment_text: I went on birth control at 16 and stayed on it most of my life. I had such heavy painful periods my mother took me to her old school doctor and he refused to give them to me. This was in the 1970’s. So…I rocked down to my local Planned Parenthood and had the most positive, well-informed experience about birth control. I knew it was a risk but it was a life changing experience. I was on the pill most of my adult life with light periods, no acne, and less emotional ups and downs. I still had my emotional bouts just before menstruation, but nothing crazy. By 40 my doctor said to stop taking them. And when I did, all the heavy periods came back, the same extreme pain and acne as well. I proceeded to try every hormone balancing med compound-natural and homeopathic medicines. It was a nightmare. I got an ultrasound on my abdomen and they found fibroids and endometriosis. Tumors on my ovaries. I was a raging, uncontrollable biach. I got a radical hysterectomy at 46 yo and never looked back. Been taking low dosage HRT estrogen for 18 years. I still deal with belly fat but need to address exercise. No more pain and emotional roller coasters though. Hot flashes without the estrogen. Balanced out my body but changed my skin for sure.

comment_text:
I am 25 years old. I know in my core that I have PMDD, my body created it because I was full of trauma, pain and depression before when I was a child because my family had some issues with infidelity and almost had a broken family.

PMDD is a chronic illness. Before am not sure why and how does my body created it and now I understand it because I deepen my spirituality because I had no choice. PMDD is a crucial thing to have, it's unpredictable, every single month. I went to gynecologist, psychiatrist and they offered me psychotherapy and oral medication which is both expensive here in the Philippines, so I have to be wise to choose because those both need finances.

Then I connected with God instead because sharing it to my family and friends are truly devastating because they couldn't understand what I need. Now, I know that it was created because of all the version of my inner child. It was created for me to listen to what my body need. I have healed and faced most of my trauma, breaking generational curses in my family and now taking care of my body, by drinking supplements that my body need and having a grounded and calm nervous system because that's how my inner child felt safe with me.

This interview may sound expensive for some, but all we need are awareness. I am still not clinically diagnosed but I am much sure that I have PMDD because I am tracking it for almost 8 months and I'm doing pretty good by maintaining it, knowing my symptoms and giving my inner child the support that I need because they mostly show up when I'm in my luteal phase. I gave them the space for every version and this technique is called, "shadow work".

All of these, I researched carefully because I need to be cautious on supplements I need to take and what kind of affirmation, diet and exercise I need to do in every phases.

To everyone, I know it's very difficult to understand yourself but take your time. As long as you're alive, you got the time to understand yourself, just be patient. If you don't know what to do, pray. If you have the privilege to have therapist, ask a lot of questions and if you're just like me.. Keep going. Everything's gonna be okay.

God bless everyone!

Then I came across The Hidden Herbs by Anette Ray, and it felt like rediscovering a part of me that had been asleep. comment_text: I'm 55 now and at the end of December I stopped taking the progeserone only pill as i had suffered from heavy periods since the birth of my 2nd son 18 yrs ago. In March I had the most heaviest period ever and had scans which showed a fibroid and endometrium lining of 9mm. The dr wanted me to have biopsy etc, but I knew after a lot of research and having a fat belly for many yrs was due to high levels of stress with my 1st son who had undiagnosed ADHD and ODD until he was 14 yrs old. Coping with his behaviour I relied on choc bars, high carb stress eating. Together with lack of sleep, bad diet, through the roof stress, being unhappy with my marriage, cortisol levels rocketed, diet prob causing insulin resistance, being in the pill etc etc over many years can cause oestrogen dominance which in turn can cause thickening of the endo lining. All the drs were concerned about was biopsies, and concern for cancer etc etc without actually looking at my history. I declined and am now not on any meds etc and starting with a clean slate taking magnesium, and B6 which can help the liver get rid of excess oestrogen. Its amazing when you research all this actually how much the hormones affect you and affect each other. Just want to add I recently asked my drs if i could have my oestrogen and progesterone levels tested and receptionist said I'd have to ask the doctor if thats something that we do! Like, you have to get permission to have these tests. I thought you know what, I'll go private and get them done myself

You don't need any fancy or complicated tests to know your cortisol levels. It's just a blood test.  My GP at Kaiser ordered an am cortisol test for me, which I'm happy to say,. turned out normal. 
Also, achieving better overall health is not complicated or mysterious. Eat a balanced diet of whole foods (mostly vegetables, fruit, and a little protein), stay away from drugs and alcohol, get a good night's sleep, and exercise 30 minutes a day. video_title: Hormone Expert: Control Your Hormones Control Your Belly Fat! Cortisol, oestrogen, testosterone.
comment_text: I don't think everything relates to human nutrition anymore. We have been told to eat 3 meals and 2 snacks. Have cereals in the morning. With the years this has changed. Hormones are part of us. Nobody in the medical sector will voluntarily send you to check your hormones if you don't feel well. I been asking my doctor to check my cortisol for years. Still didn't do it. I will go back to my country and I will go privately and check all my hormones. My heart rate variability has been very low for more than 10 years. video_title: Hormone Expert: Control Your Hormones Control Your Belly Fat! Cortisol, oestrogen, testosterone.
comment_text: Our bodies are chemical factories. humans were not designed to live in a constant state of fear, yet we are conditioned to live in fear: fear of loosing our job, our home, fear of becoming homeless, fear of cancer, fear of dementia. I could probably write for a month with no sleep listing all the fears that we are subjected to constantly, not just by the media, corporations, etc but also at peer level. Our bodies live in a state of constant alert and stress. This adds to the internal stress caused by the body lacking nutrients and trying to send signals of distress using guess what? cortisol. Cortisol is a survival hormone. When people are in survival, many other physiological functions and hormone productions are deemed unessential by the brain. Despite having no predators, no real danger we live in survival mode and we live on fat free, cholesterol free diets when hormones can't be produced without cholesterol.

comment_text:
I'm 57 and my wife of 17 years and I just divorced last year and contributing factors were definitely perimenopausal and menopausal symptoms that lasted for 10 years. it was an immediate switch, almost like when you love the scent of someone, that just turned off. I tired to communicate about it, "hey we still have our relationship, let's work on it", etc. but no success. She ended up also having an affair and that sealed the deal. I kicked her out and divorced her. No relationship is perfect, we tried to work on it, and this was our 2nd marriage but we always had a fiery passion. Then it just stopped. By the time we understood we could have gone to our doctor or find fixes, it was too late. We were amicable on the split, I decided to play to good karma and wanted us to live our separate lives in peace, despite the betrayal.

I'm now the happiest I've ever been. My house is happy and lively, my kids (in their 20's) come around with their friends, I cook for them and enjoy being a part of their lives as I also live my own. With my two rescue dogs, life is as peaceful as ever. I wish her well too, although there is no reason to talk anymore. Life moves on and I embrace it. If and when I'm ready, "the one" is out there. 😀

video_title: Hormone Expert: Control Your Hormones Control Your Belly Fat! Cortisol, oestrogen, testosterone.
comment_text:
I started working with a nutritionist who helped me understand pre-menopause and guided me on what to ask my doctor. I had a full hormone panel and insulin test (cost ~$220, but some are covered by MSP). Balancing hormones is key to preventing heart issues, arthritis, and more. Bioidentical options like Prometrium (progesterone) and Climara (estradiol patch) are recommended.

Diet-wise, focus on protein, avoid sugar and processed carbs, and opt for low-glycemic veggies (sweet potatoes, cabbage, broccoli). Managing insulin resistance? Weight training and possibly low-dose Mounjaro help. Supplements like Vit D+K2, Magnesium Glycinate, and B12 can be beneficial.

Prioritizing health over luxury trips, I invested in tests and lifestyle changes. It’s not easy, but persistence pays off—your health is your responsibility!
My knowledgeable not very expensive certified nutritionist Dana Mircioiu Nutritional Therapy Practitioner, BSc.
Restart Instructor, Women‘s Health, Peri-Menopause 
www.letscreatehealth.com

comment_text:
Wow, frozen shoulder?? That's another symptom of perimenopause my doctors missed in my 30s. I had an early onset with a slew of symptoms that no one warned me about, i was diagnosed several years after symptoms began, by which time i was in a hellishly bad way. I then went through the worst of it while coming to terms with such early onset. 
Luckily, at 44 I've fully post-menopausal for 3 years and life is good, I'm healthy, getting my energy back and making huge lifestyle changes to improve my future ✊️ if you are going through early menopause, please know it gets better and you will get your self-love back, with interest! Hang in there, ladies, it will be ok!! 💖

video_title: Hormone Expert: Control Your Hormones Control Your Belly Fat! Cortisol, oestrogen, testosterone.
comment_text:
What if Dr. Sara has identified some correlations but made the wrong diagnosis when it comes to fiber and the patriarchy?

FIBER: She believes the theory that a diversity of dietary fiber causes microbiome diversity which causes positive health outcomes. Didn't Dr. Benjamin Bikman say that fiber and microbiome diversity is an unproven theory? What if, instead, fiber is unnecessary but indicative of the following three things:
 1) Lots of fiber tends to dumb down the insulin levels from glucose
 2) More fiber means you get fuller with fewer calories (less likely to be overweight and this could have similar effects to fasting)
 3) The higher glycemic diet one eats, the more of many nutrients their body requires. What if Dr Sara's focus on filling, low glucose plants helps her get sufficient micronutrients?

PATRIARCHY: She believes that the patriarchy is causing women to be under more stress and that this stress is causing women negative health outcomes. What if biology and feminism are to blame?
 - What if women evolved to be high in neuroticism and agreeableness in order to care for infants, and this leads to their higher stress and being taken advantage of (channeling Dr Jordan Peterson here). So no "social construct," just evolution.
 - What if because of being designed to create life female bodies are hormonally way more complex/delicate than male bodies? What if this leads to more easily triggered hormonal disbalance in women vs men when poor diet, poor exercise, addictive behaviors, and hormone disruptors are at play?
 - What if women, men, marriages, and most importantly children would be happier and less stressed if we prioritized motherhood and prized its infinite value (channeling Dr Erica Komisar)? What if women focusing on the power of providing instead of the power of nurturing has caused them and children to be more stressed? Is it any coincidence that our nutrition went out the window as women stopped physically nurturing children as much and went full-time into the workforce while their children went to nannies and daycare and were fed by pre-made/processed food? Is it any coincidence that our society has become more anxious the more we separated children from their mothers? Perhaps even full-time k-12 is more daycare than school, leading more mothers to mother less and be in the workforce more. In other words, feminism and the government driving women out of their role as mothers and women joining the patriarchy is what has hurt women's health. We want to eat more like our hunter-gatherer ancestors, but that's just one piece of being like them. Another huge component is that hunter-gatherer mothers are with their children constantly as infants and very often as kids, and one full-time mother isn't enough to fill the mother role. Her "village" includes aunts and grandmothers, nieces and older daughters filling the huge role of "Mother." This hunter-gatherer role of Female or Mother is incompatible with a full-time working mom, maybe even a full-time working aunt or grandmother. Are working moms stressed with juggling work and family? Yes. Is their "village" of nannies and daycare workers that are inconsistent in a child's life a suitable replacement for Mother? No. Are SAHM stressed because their village stopped existing when neighboring mothers and their kids abandoned them for the workforce and daycare? Yes.

I think living by the narrative of power and oppression is causing many people, including doctors, to draw the wrong diagnosis. Perhaps a better life narrative is: family. Harmony and happiness are most likely to be achieved when we prioritize family and balance the roles of men/fathers and women/mothers. But the role of Mother has been abandoned.

The fact that women are now dealing with everything our previous generations did, plus working…And not just working but now we have the added pressures on ourselves of comparing ourselves to social media figures, is so much more than our nervous systems were designed for.  We were never supposed to do it all and look what the trajectory has done to modern men. We have children that have so many different problems growing up bc even if the mother is there, she’s unlikely to be fully present. The social standards for men have lowered to non existent. They don’t know what to do with themselves. Women are suffering menopause sooner. The feminist movement wanted respect, consideration and options. Now being everything to all people is disrespecting ourselves and making it impossible to rest and repair. We’re comparing ourselves to people who aren’t even real.  Like many social structures…we’re supposed to overdo an idea and then find equilibrium. But we keep pushing the pendulum.

comment_text:
@@tns4358this is true, but the act of sitting down and doing rather than being creative or waiting for the creative juices to flow - can work wonders for stress levels.
I accidentally introduced myself to art therapy - literally throwing paint ons canvas and spreading it with my hands - not because I was in a creative mood but because I was angry and hurt and needed those emotions to be “put somewhere” outside of my body. 
That Sunday - 6 hours later - I had created one of my best pairings ever! 
It looks like a vortex, a storm, a tunnel, an eye… according to any one who sees it… it’s the piece that everyone is drawn to when then enter my home… 
So yes it’s true you can’t feel creative in a stressed state, but you can still create something especially if you let go of expectations about what you’re going to create and just let it all go into whatever you’re doing - and sometimes really surprise yourself.

Having said that, I have never knitted or crocheted in anger, so I suppose there are limitations. 😉😂

video_title: Hormone Expert: Control Your Hormones Control Your Belly Fat! Cortisol, oestrogen, testosterone.
comment_text: My childless partner is going thru perimenopause. And I have a theory. When a woman becomes pregnant, their hormone changes slowly during that process. After giving birth, hormones are yet again changed over the course of post pregnancy. Then menopause hits. Hormones are yet again activated. All the above is spread out over time (collectively). A woman who doesn’t have children? Gets all the above hormonal changes,imbalances, and cycles…..all in one shot. And not spread out over “time”.  This is only my own opinion and what I’ve seen (I’m in no way claiming I am right or wrong).Either way, I fully sympathize for what women go thru during menopause process.

comment_text: I am a healthy eater, grow a lot of my own food, yet I suffered for  years with premenopausal, menopausal  symptoms. I want to share what helped me tremendously. I have a smoothie every morning with a bit of frozen berries, half a teaspoon of powdered cinnamon, half a teaspoon of turmeric powder, a bit of stevia, a teaspoon of powdered greens. I take Vit D with K2 supplement, DIM supplement, B complex, Zinc. I started making yogurt with probiotic reuteri - I make a few batches every few months. My symptoms slowly disappeared, belly fat melted away (I haven't had a beautiful belly for years!), bloating gone ( I suffered so much with that! ), brain function improved, energy levels improved,  I still get night sweats, but a lot less. I do walk 3 miles a few times a week and excercise with weights at home a bit. I eat veggies and eggs, meat, sardines. Best of luck  darlings.

comment_text:
When I turned 50 and entered menopause, I had very few resources, and my doctors didn't explain much or seem to care.
For the past eight years, l've been going through the hell of menopause, dealing with body changes, cortisol spikes, estrogen and not knowing what the hell is happening to my body. The overwhelming feeling that I was losing my mind. Your show has provided the knowledge and clarity I needed, helping me realize I wasn't crazy. I was just going through something that so many men and women don't fully understand because doctors often avoid the truth.
Thank you Steven for addressing this important topic🙏🏽it has truly made a difference for viewers like me.
PS.. omg Dr Sara Szal nailed it❤❤❤

comment_text: There is substantial evidence showing that women report higher levels of fear and are more likely to develop anxiety disorders compared to men. This may be due to differences in brain chemistry and hormonal fluctuations. Throughout a woman’s life, reproductive events are associated with hormonal changes that have been linked to anxiety. video_title: Hormone Expert: Control Your Hormones Control Your Belly Fat! Cortisol, oestrogen, testosterone.
comment_text: 54:56 During menopause, estrogen drops, causing fat to shift from the hips and thighs to the belly (aka menobelly) and affecting insulin response, possibly leading to insulin resistance. Testosterone changes and sleep disturbances further impact fat distribution and appetite by lowering leptin (which suppresses hunger) and increasing ghrelin (which stimulates hunger). Rising Follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) levels in response to lower estrogen during menopause are linked to increased body fat. Dr. Mary Claire Haver, in "The New Menopause", cites research from the "Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism", stating that HRT significantly reduces visceral fat. However, this benefit does not extend to those who have discontinued HRT, emphasizing the need for alternative strategies if stopping treatment. Dr. Haver advises increased intake of fiber in your diet, decreased consumption of sugar, and regular exercise to combat the development of visceral fat.

comment_text: I feel they missed one question on the ACE questionnaire.  "Did you have a parent who had health problems.  Health problems that made you feel they would die" (young).  I was in elementary school when I started thinking my mother was going to die by the time she 29.  I was 5 when I had that thought.  Her first trip to the hospital was to have a grapefruit sized cyst removed from her stomach (benign), next she had to have a hysterectomy, then she dislocated her right knee.  Dr. said both knees weak.  She had her right kneecap removed.  Then surgery on other knee as preventative care so it didn't actually dislocate as that can cause more damage than necessary.  She had 8 surgeries in 11 years on her knees alone.  Then she got breast cancer (lumpectomy).  Then she got lung cancer (removed lung).  Three years later she got cancer in the other lung.  As an added bonus she had to go through radiation and chemotherapy with the lung cancers.  My mother died at 52 and I was 30.  Basically my mother was in and out of the hospital my whole childhood for different surgeries/illnesses and that really messes with your head.

comment_text: @@marienissanka9657 So true. I started menopause early at 45. I was 160 lbs (5'3) at my heaviest. Because of hormonal imbalance I also became prediabetic, high cholesterol and had thyroid issues. I was put on a bunch of medications plus HRT. The HRT literally has saved me. I also made a complete lifestyle change. Stopped drinking, started taking fiber supplements, omega 3's and vitamin D & K — all of that is good for menopausal women. But the game changer was changing my diet, cutting out sugar and alcohol and making sure I was getting some form of exercise EVERY DAY. Also having MORE boundaries with people. I no longer am prediabetic. I'm now 115 lbs. My cholesterol is in the normal zone. It took consistency, a different mindset and patience. This happened over a 5 year span. Eating healthy and excercising daily is cost-effective. Being on tons of medications and constantly getting lab work done, seeing the doctor became a huge expense for me. Becoming diabetic is EXPENISIVE. I am at the weight that i was in high school at age 50 LOL.

comment_text:
Your PCP will order these tests, you just need to use the verbiage/complaint for them to have it covered from insurance. The big thing about insurance is assessing the necessity of any test. If you go in complaining of the real symptoms you’re experiencing and request for your hormones to be tested, they’ll do it and they’ll send it to your insurance. Yes if you’re rich you have access to providers like this one, we have to do A LOT more work. But getting your labs (hormones, thyroid, Vit D etc) you can do then a video like this would be the beginning of that journey. Also…a lot, if not all, of these providers take HSA/FSA which is an insurance option for any job. Don’t pay to dollar insurance tiers for providers you don’t want in the first place, you can get the PPO which is less out of your check and match the rest in your HSA pre taxed and that would pay for these type of providers.

I look at this way, if health = wealth, no one’s gotten wealthy or rich without spending money/time 🤷‍♀️

comment_text:
Sadly the healthcare system is set up for doctor's to order the screenings that test for the most common metrics that they can easily prescribe certain medications for. Statins, blood pressure medication, insulin. Done day, easy money for pharma. Most doctors aren't trained to screen you for the purpose of finding the root problems and helping you resolve the issues permanently. 

On the bright side, these tests only help you track your progress and you dont need them to start fixing your health. Diet really is the key to solving most chronic health conditions. What matters is what the diet consists of. A low inflammatory diet. Dr. William Davis is a great place to start, as his usual lecture explains this very well. If you make your gut healthy, free of inflammation- you'll find the hormones, and maybe other surprising things, start to fall in place.

video_title: Hormone Expert: Control Your Hormones Control Your Belly Fat! Cortisol, oestrogen, testosterone.
comment_text: It’s extremely rare for someone to be allergic to all vegetables, but it’s possible to have multiple vegetable allergies or a broad sensitivity. Some people have oral allergy syndrome (OAS), where their immune system reacts to proteins in raw vegetables that resemble pollen allergens. Others may have true IgE-mediated allergies to specific vegetables. However, a total allergy to every vegetable would be highly unusual and would likely stem from an underlying immune system disorder or extreme food sensitivities rather than traditional allergies.

comment_text:
She said “prevention is a hard thing to sell.” And “a lot of people don’t want to invest in prevention“
It’s not that a lot of people don’t want to invest in it.  It’s just that a lot of people are living paycheck to paycheck and cannot afford to “invest in prevention“ and you might say well then it’s gonna cost them more in the long run. That may be so, but they don’t live in the future. They live in right now and right now they need to keep a roof over their head and food in their kids mouths, and clothes on their back. And so they can’t afford to spend 1000, 3000, $5000 on preventative tests  that are going to show them what changes they need to make in order to live longer or to not get a disease or to not exacerbate a condition that they don’t have any control over. 
I look at all the people that I would love to work for or work with to help make preventative medical practice more accessible to the average Joe. 
But I also am the average Joe. And while I understand the concepts behind genetic testing and DNA and cortisol, and all the things that I’m battling as a menopausal woman with ADHD. And my doctor see me as difficult because I won’t just take a pill to cover up my symptoms because pharmaceuticals and I do not get along.
I understand how hard it is and how expensive it is to do alternative routes  and it’s just not feasible for the majority of Americans. 
How can we change that?  How can I be a part of that change?

I feel like from experience the best cope(not cure ) youre going to get it:
-exercise 20 minutes or less calisthenics, pilates or slow weighted workout(view youre workout as physical therapy)
-walk, walk walk some more preferable outside perhaps with a pet 🐕 
-sleep is important (naps are good)
-Cut back on caffeine and hydrate with water and water heavy fruits and veg.
-mindfulness(puzzles, crochet, mechanical, woodworking etc)
-find purpose in helping others
-low carb, sugar free(for some gluten and dairy free). Pretend you're a diabetic and act accordingly.

Common sense things but not always easy to start.

comment_text: Great list and I’d just like to add eating only whole foods (I eat very little that comes out of a packet and even then it must have no additives, preservatives or any weird unpronounceable crap!) and little to no alcohol. I’ve  followed this nearly all my adult life as well as being vegetarian and never taking the contraceptive pill. I’m 57 and post menopausal and apart from a few hot flushes in the beginning have had no other real symptoms or problems. I’m convinced my lifestyle is the magic formula which has set me up for such an easy transition. Although convenient for women, I’m also convinced that messing with the natural hormones in the body can’t be a good thing which is why I never took the pill, so that might also be why I’ve had an easy time with menopause. Have also barely taken any medication as never have any illnesses needing them. Oh and another thing, feed your gut biome with fermented foods. Just wanted to throw a few things out here that I’m convinced have helped me in case they can help someone else or even someone young enough to be wanting to make lifestyle changes that will help ease them into the inevitable aging of their bodies.

comment_text: A very interesting discussion, somewhat self-sabotaged by the pointless (but fashionable) notion that there is something "patriarchal " in the concept of healing people (around 3.00). And then "patriarchy" raises its ugly head again around 1.34.50, along with the notion that women experience more trauma than men for reasons that are not biological. But how can they not be? Women are physically more vulnerable because they have (on average) less body strength. video_title: Hormone Expert: Control Your Hormones Control Your Belly Fat! Cortisol, oestrogen, testosterone.
comment_text:
Every body is different. Genetics plays a huge role in this, as well. 

Now 55, but went through menopause at 53. Ate extremely healthy, cardio daily, BMI 20 throughout life. Symptoms at 53 were anxiety and 15lb weight gain within a few weeks. 

Ate less, no sugar or carbs, more cardio, and gained 5lb more. 

Then researched more and upped my calories.. making protein 1g to every lb, cut cardio (except walking), started weight training 4x/week (1hr). The weight is SLOWLY coming off. But I've gained muscle. 

It's a lot of work for me even eating well, exercising, sleeping 7.5hr, and stress management. On HRT (low dose).. 

Every person will have a different experience. Much of the time, the things that you did pre-meno, will no longer work. 

But for many, it's going to be very rigorous.

comment_text:
I have found the perfect diet. It’s easy. And simple to live with forever. It’s called The Carbohydrate Addict’s Diet. Basically it’s eating one carbohydrate meal a day. Anything for one hour. The other meal is very low carb. Like steak and eggs. No toast and jelly. Or tofu and broccoli. Or pickles olives or cheese. Salad! No croutons and careful about the dressing. No more than four carbs. Nuts yes. That’s the idea. It works. By not releasing insulin more than once daily. Try to stick to the same meal. I’ve chosen lunch as my “ carb meal “. I’m telling you that 36 hours in and all cravings and hunger is gone. I do kinda focus pretty good on that carb meal though cuz it’s my treat. I eat pretty healthy anyway. Fruit is my dessert. But you could literally eat pizza and donuts for only that one hour a day. You lose between 1&2 pounds a week. So maybe 50+ pounds in a year. Add any healthy activity of course. But for the diet it’s unnecessary… 🤷🏼‍♀️ 
Research it. There’s a book. By the diet’s name. Blessings in all truth.

video_title: Hormone Expert: Control Your Hormones Control Your Belly Fat! Cortisol, oestrogen, testosterone.
comment_text:
Menopause is not a thing in all ethnic populations.

My girlfriends and me tried an  experiment with hot flushes.

...we heard the rumour that the more Hot flushes women had , there might be an issue with shame & guilt & denial about sexuality and arousal - the solution was to own these part of us proactively.

So the treatment was to mentally allow these THOUGHTS when a flush approached.

We found out that the amount and intensity of hot flushes seemed to relate to the amount of unconscious shame - has lots to do with internalized guilt, shame, and trauma from abuse. Not just sexual abuse, also emotional abuse, when a parent used you to meet their own emotional needs - the chain of pain. 

Not all of us, but many of us felt this taboo needed to become conscious and unlocked, and the flushes started to get balanced quicker. It's not about doing anything, but rather of admitting to yourself that that cultural taboo is in fact there and allowed to go. 

Hope this helps some of you wom(b)en.

comment_text:
Supposedly cardio isn't such a good option. It placed stress on you which leads to cortisol and then belly fat.

 Some low impact sort of aerobics is better. But absolutely essential is: LIFTING WEIGHTS. 

I dropped a few kilos almost immediately after my last session of weight training, pilates and Low Impact Training (aerobics). 
Also, look at whether lowering carb intake helps you lose weight. Increase vegetable intake. I eat cruciferous veg everyday. Some fasting days are also usually totally necessary for any older people to keep weight down.

Also: buy a weighted vest and go walking. You'll get your aerobic workout with your weight training all in one. Go walking daily
There are even videos on YouTube about how to get a good practise of this established.

comment_text:
Hang in there! One of the best ways to overcome depression is to take action, even when your mind and body resist. That’s not just how you survive—it’s how you heal, overcome, and thrive. You have more control than you may feel right now. Visualize your ideal life and start taking small, intentional steps as if you are already on that path.

Find a trusted accountability partner—preferably someone of the same sex—who can encourage you and remind you of the truth when your thoughts try to pull you down. Over time, your brain can become your greatest asset in maintaining a healthy, fulfilling life.

And if you’re struggling deeply, don’t hesitate to seek help from a trusted friend, coach, therapist, or doctor. You are not alone, and the right support can make all the difference. You’ve got this!

comment_text: Hello, I read your post and it is really concerning. Because I have a friend who had a hysterectomy and (most importantly) her ovaries removed, and she developed autoimmune disorders/chronic pain as well as intense depression. She ended her life last year which absolutely breaks my heart. People in your life need you and love you and want you to feel better. hysterectomies drastically affect your hormone production and your mental health. you need to see someone as soon as possible who can help you with the extreme hormonal deficit you’re probably experiencing. I had a shitty time with perimenopause but a hysterectomy does so much more mental health damage if the hormonal balance is not addressed and it’s way worse. You can find help, you could start with telling someone who cares about you what is going on and seeing where you can get free support (like a suicide hotline) and go from there, if money is a barrier. I’m so sorry you’re going through this it sounds like hell and if I can even nudge you a tiny bit to take one action for yourself it will be a gift coming from my own sorrow and experience with my friend. Take good care please, and don’t ignore what is happening. It’s not your fault you took doctors advice on something, that’s what we are taught is that doctors know what we need. Sometimes they’re right but sometimes they’re wrong. Sending prayers for your well bring and recovery. 🙏🏻🙏🏻🙏🏻🙏🏻🙏🏻❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️

video_title: Hormone Expert: Control Your Hormones Control Your Belly Fat! Cortisol, oestrogen, testosterone.
comment_text: Menopause causes a lot of stress in the body as estrogen depletes and cortisol rises. (Estrogen isn’t just a sex hormone, it acts to regulate many things in the body.) On top of this, we lose muscle as we get older.  Muscle is the “sink” for glucose, so when we lose muscle, we lose the place where sugar is stored so that the sugar rises in the bloodstream.  Insulin then rises because insulin is how we “mop up” the sugar.  What you are describing with the belly fat is insulin resistance.  Unfortunately, you have to reduce sugar because the next stage after insulin resistance is diabetes.  Another thing you need to do is to eat more protein and weight train.  You have lost muscle and need to regain it by lifting weights.  A treadmill will help you lose weight, but it won’t build the muscle you need to help with the insulin resistance and belly fat.  I’m 59 and wish I had been told this earlier.

video_title: Hormone Expert: Control Your Hormones Control Your Belly Fat! Cortisol, oestrogen, testosterone.
comment_text:
I'm so so sorry you are going through this and know how it feels.... belly fat and fibroid pain can be debilitating... I've been there and still live with it but am steadily getting my life back... a couple of suggestions that have helped me:
Find your trigger foods... for me dairy is a massive trigger food... gluten less so and also sugar, and chilli... I still eat a lot of sugar but I find if I minimise the others I can get away with it... some people also react to caffeine so look into that....

Heal your gut... most of this will be to do with inflammation - look up the anti inflammatory diet, take a strong probiotic, omega 3 fish oil and magnesium... you'll be amazed at how much healing your gut will improve your overall wellbeing...

Joy is incredibly important... I was doing loads pushing myself to do all the right things - 15000 steps, cutting everything in my diet - it drove my stress up and my depression through the roof... then I went on holidays, was super happy and my body let go of a lot of weight and all my pain went away... do things that make you happy... I know its not easy given where u are but start small... perhaps with a walk outside and build on that...

For fibroid pain I take PONSTAN (tablet) as well as nurofen and paracetamol and also use a infra-red heated belt... helps a lot 

Fasting doesn't work for everyone... it has worked wonders for my sister but causes horrendous bloating for me so listen to you body and see what works for you.

As everyone has mentioned, consider weight lifting :)

Give yourself 3 months, it will get worse before it gets better but stick with it, be gentle with yourself, I hope you feel better very soon xxx
